message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest hyperandrogenemia, as seen in PCOS, CAH, Turner syndrome, and Aromatase deficiency. The patient’s severe acne, clitoromegaly, and abnormal hair growth point towards Aromatase deficiency, which affects estrogen production, leading to hyperandrogenemia. The patient’s refusal to have a pelvic exam can be due to the presence of masculinizing features, which may have caused gender dysphoria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help.The patient’s symptoms, such as clitoromegaly, abnormal hair growth, and fractures, suggest a disorder in androgen synthesis pathway. Among the options, aromatase deficiency is the most likely diagnosis as it can cause virilization and osteoporosis, and females with the condition will have normal internal genitalia. Polycystic ovary syndrome and Turner syndrome often present with infertility, and congenital adrenal hyperplasia may cause ambiguous genitalia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including clitoromegaly, abnormal hair growth, and early fractures, suggest androgen excess. Among the options, only aromatase deficiency can cause these symptoms. Polycystic ovary syndrome can cause menstrual irregularities, but it is unlikely to cause clitoromegaly and early fractures. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia typically presents in infancy and childhood, and Turner syndrome typically presents with amenorrhea and short stature. The patient’s normal uterus on pelvic ultrasound also supports the diagnosis of aromatase deficiency, as Turner syndrome would typically show a streaked or absent uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest an endocrine disorder, likely involving hyperandrogenism. Among the options, only Aromatase Deficiency leads to increased androgens and a lack of estrogen, leading to delayed puberty and osteoporosis. Polycystic ovary syndrome and Congenital adrenal hyperplasia can cause similar symptoms, but a normal uterus on pelvic ultrasound makes them less likely. Turner Syndrome is not a likely diagnosis based on the given information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest an androgen excess, which can be caused by multiple conditions, but the fact that she broke her wrist after a minor trauma and has a spinal compression fracture suggests decreased bone mineral density, which is a symptom of aromatase deficiency. The pelvic ultrasound showing multiple ovarian cysts is also a hallmark symptom of polycystic ovary syndrome, but the patient's bone issues make aromatase deficiency a more likely diagnosis. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia and Turner syndrome would have different physical exam findings and/or laboratory values.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including clitoromegaly, abnormal hair growth, and multiple fractures, suggest a disorder of androgen excess, and among the options, only Aromatase deficiency fits. Polycystic ovary syndrome can present with menstrual irregularities and ovarian cysts, but it doesn’t explain the other symptoms. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia can also cause androgen excess, but it typically presents with salt wasting and hypotension. Turner syndrome typically presents with short stature, webbed neck, and ovarian failure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of clitoromegaly, abnormal hair growth, and fractures suggest a possible diagnosis of aromatase deficiency. Polycystic ovary syndrome can also cause ovarian cysts but the patient’s other symptoms suggest otherwise. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia usually has symptoms starting in infancy or childhood. Turner syndrome would result in primary amenorrhea and other physical findings that are not present in the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has clitoromegaly, abnormal hair growth, and osteoporotic fractures, which suggest an androgen excess. The patient’s external female genitalia appear normal, and a pelvic ultrasound shows ovaries with multiple cysts, which suggest anovulation. Among the options, Aromatase deficiency is the most likely diagnosis as it presents with androgen excess and anovulation, with normal female genitalia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of excessive androgen production, including clitoromegaly, abnormal hair growth, severe acne, and a history of fractures, which is consistent with aromatase deficiency. The normal uterus on pelvic ultrasound also supports this diagnosis, as the syndrome is not associated with infertility. Polycystic ovary syndrome may present similarly, but the presence of clitoromegaly and a normal uterus make it less likely. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia presents with ambiguous genitalia in females, which is not present in this patient. Turner syndrome is characterized by short stature and ovarian failure, which are not present in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms including clitoromegaly, abnormal hair growth, and multiple cysts in the ovaries suggest Aromatase deficiency. Polycystic ovary syndrome is also possible but the patient’s breast development is at Tanner stage I, which is not consistent with this diagnosis. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia and Turner syndrome can also present with menstrual irregularities and ovarian cysts, but their other symptoms do not match those of the patient.
